Fig. 1 XRD patterns of the different samples. Fig 1 Fig. 2 Raman spectra of Ce3.5Co0.5AC, Ce0.5Co3.5AC and Ce3.5Co3.5AC. Fig 2 Fig. 3 SEM images of Ce3.5Co3.5AC. Fig 3 Fig. 4 (a) O2-TPD curves of Ce3.5Co0.5AC, Ce0.5Co3.5AC, Ce1.5Co1.5AC, Ce2.5Co2.5AC, Ce3.5Co3.5AC, (b) the corresponding O2 consumption. Fig 4 Fig. 5 (a) H2-TPR curves of Ce3.5Co0.5AC, Ce0.5Co3.5AC, Ce1.5Co1.5AC, Ce2.5Co2.5AC, Ce3.5Co3.5AC and (b) the corresponding H2 consumption. Fig 5 Fig. 6 XPS of O 1s (a), Co 2p (b), Ce 3d (c) of all catalysts. Fig 6 Fig. 7 (a, b) Toluene conversions over different catalysts under simulated gas conditions. Reaction conditions: [toluene] = 1000 ppm, [O2] = 20 %, N2 as balance, WHSV = 110,000 ml·g−1·h−1. (c, d) Corresponding CO2 yield. (e, f) Catalyst activation energy over various samples. Fig 7 Fig. 8 (a) The water resistance tests and (b) stability test over Ce3.5Co3.5AC. Reaction conditions: [toluene] = 1000 ppm, [O2] = 20 %, N2 as balance, WHSV = 110,000 ml·g−1·h−1, T = 250 ℃, water = 10 Vol% (when used). Fig 8 Fig. 9 Effects of toluene concentration (a) and WHSV (b) over Ce3.5Co3.5AC. Fig 9 Fig. 10 In situ DRIFTS over of toluene + N2 on Ce3.5Co3.5AC (a) and AC (c) at different temperature; results of Ce3.5Co3.5AC (b) and AC (d) after injection of 20 % O2/N2 at 200 ℃; Ce3.5Co3.5AC characteristic IR peak area of surface alcohol salt and benzoate species versus time during reaction (e). Fig 10 Fig. 11 The relationship between reaction rate (T = 250 ℃), Ov concentration, Olatt/Oads ration, surface Co3+/Co2+ ratio and surface Ce3+/Ce4+ ratio concentration. Fig 11 Table 1 Structure parameters of various catalysts and raw AC. Table 3 Catalyst Toluene concentration/ppm Airspeed T90/℃ reference CoCeOx/Beta-60 1000 10,000 GHSV 307 [51] Co0.2Ce0.8O2-δ 1000 20,000 GHSV 230 [52] 30Co-Ce 1000 120,000 WHSV 262 [62] Ce0.4Co1Ox/IM 800 12,000 GHSV 256 [63] Co5Ce1Ox 1000 135,000 WHSV 277 [39] Ce–Co 1000 30,000 GHSV 203 [64] 10 % Co-5 % Ce/SPC 1000 20,000 GHSV 200 [65] Ce3.5Co3.5AC 1000 110,000 WHSV 246 This work Review Paper CeCoOx/AC catalysts with synergistic effect for toluene catalytic oxidation: Insights into the contribution of lattice oxygen content and superior oxygen mobility Yuanyuan Yang Writing – original draft Methodology Investigation Formal analysis a Yunbin Xia Methodology Investigation a Ganxue Wu Writing – review & editing Supervision Funding acquisition Formal analysis Conceptualization a ⁎ Mingli Li Methodology a Ziyue Lan Investigation a Mengjia Zhu Methodology a Rui Wang Methodology a Yinghao Chu Supervision Conceptualization b a College of Environmental Science, Sichuan Agricultural University, Chengdu, Sichuan, China College of Environmental Science Sichuan Agricultural University Chengdu Sichuan China aCollege of Environmental Science, Sichuan Agricultural University, Chengdu, Sichuan, China b College of Architecture and Environment, Sichuan University, Chengdu, Sichuan, China College of Architecture and Environment Sichuan University Chengdu Sichuan China bCollege of Architecture and Environment, Sichuan University, Chengdu, Sichuan, China ⁎ Corresponding author at: College of Environmental Science, Sichuan Agricultural University, Chengdu, Sichuan, 611130, China. College of Environmental Science Sichuan Agricultural University Chengdu Sichuan 611130 China A series of CeCoOx/AC catalysts using leather waste based activated carbon as the carrier were prepared by a modified impregnation method, and the catalytic performance of toluene oxidation was investigated. Among them, Ce3.5Co3.5AC catalyst with Ce and Co loading being both 3.5 wt% exhibited the optimal catalytic activity (T90 = 246 ℃). SEM (Scanning Electron Microscope), Raman, XRD (X-ray Diffraction), H2-TPR (Hydrogen Temperature Programmed Reduction), O2-TPD (Oxygen Temperature Programmed Desorption) and XPS (X-ray Photoelectron Spectroscopy) characterization results revealed that there is interaction between Ce and Co, leading to improved redox ability and oxygen mobility, more oxygen vacancies and lattice oxygen, higher Ce3+/Ce4+ and Co3+/Co2+ ratio, multi-factorial synergies which are positively responsible for its superior catalytic activity. Additionally, the in situ DRIFTS results on Ce3.5Co3.5AC catalyst verified that benzyl alcohol, benzoate are the main intermediates. Meanwhile, Ce3.5Co3.5AC catalyst has good resistance ability to water (10 Vol%) and catalytic stability, which has the potential to be applied in practice. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Leather waste Activated carbon Toluene catalytic oxidation Synergistic effect Data availability The authors do not have permission to share data. 1 Introduction VOCs (Volatile organic compounds) is a complex composition of organic pollutants, with toxic and odorous characteristics, which is widely distributed in the atmosphere. It is harmful to human health and environment, and can cause human respiratory diseases, meanwhile it is an important precursor of PM2.5 and O3[1,2]. It is wildly accepted that VOCs can not only react with atmospheric sulfur dioxide and nitrogen oxides to form photochemical smog, but also can interact with strong atmospheric oxidants (e.g., -OH and O3) to generate secondary aerosols[3]. With the acceleration of industrialization, the annual VOCs emissions are gradually increasing, in order to effectively control the trend, some laws and regulations have been promulgated by different government agencies. Therefore, developing efficient VOCs purification technologies is the key. Various elimination strategies such as adsorption[1], catalytic combustion, biofiltration, incineration[4], thermal combustion, etc. have been developed to remove VOC. Among them, low temperature catalytic combustion is considered to be one of the most promising technologies for VOC abatement[5], due to its several advantages including high removal efficiency, thermally robust stability and few by-products[6]. The key for VOC removal using catalytic oxidation technology is to exploit efficient catalysts with excellent low-temperature activity, high selectivity and stability, energy-saving and that satisfy industrial cost requirements[7,8]. Various catalysts have been developed in the last twenty years, and generally categorized into two types: noble metal (Pd, Pt, Au and Ru) and transition metal (Mn, Co, Cr, Ni, etc.) oxide catalysts[9]. The noble metal based VOC catalysts display good low-temperature catalytic activity, they have been used in a wide range of industrial applications. Nevertheless, there are still some drawbacks including the considerably-high cost due to its low abundance in nature, sintering risk and prone to surface poisoning[10]. Metal oxides(Mn, Ce, Co, Cu), especially mixed metal oxides(MnCuOx, CeCoOx, CuCeOx), having some unique advantages including low cost, advanced thermal stability and low secondary pollution, attract most researchers’ attention, and are considered to be the focus of future efforts to develop efficient VOCs catalysts[1,11]. CeO2 is considered as one of the promising metal components for the VOCs catalysts due to the reason that it has excellent oxygen storage and release capacity[12]. Carabineiro et al. [13] prepared a series of Ce-Co composite metal oxides by external mold method and studied their catalytic oxidation performance of toluene, their results suggest that the as-prepared catalysts have a relatively low ignition temperature as low as 250 ℃. Jinpeng et al. [14] synthesized a CeO2 catalyst with doping a small amount of CoOx, and regulated the morphologies by adjusting the CoOx doping ratio, they found that CoOx-CeO2 nanoparticles with CoOx doping ratios being 1 % showed the optimal activity for toluene oxidation (T90 = 86 ℃). Additionally, Co3O4 was also widely used for VOCs catalytic oxidation. Moreover, the nature and distribution characteristics of the cobalt oxide species can determine the activity and selectivity of the loaded catalysts. For example, Liotta et al. perceived there is a synergistic effect between Ce and Co in the Co3O4-CeO2 mixed oxides catalysts on the catalytic oxidation toluene activity, which is attributed to the increment in specific surface area and the improved redox performance[15]. In addition, T. Konsolakisa et al.[16] investigate the impact of reduction pretreatment and Ce/Co ratios on the redox properties of Ce-Co complex oxides and found that the synergistic effect between Ce and Co species highly benefits for its catalytic oxidation activity. Reducing the cost, gaining a high conversion efficiency at low temperature is an important goal for the mixed metal oxides based VOCs catalyst. For the designing of efficient VOCs catalyst, the choice of catalytic carrier is another important factor besides active components. Activated carbon has been widely used as catalyst carriers or adsorption materials for VOCs abatement in commercial applications because of its wide source, large specific surface area, high surface affinity for most VOCs, and excellent adsorption performance[17,18]. So, designing of oxidation catalyst by loading some active metals onto the activated carbon combined with thermal catalysis is considered as one of the effective strategies[19,20]. The leather industry is one of the most environmentally destructive industries, the traditional method of recycling chromium in leather waste by incineration is prone to induce a series of problems including a huge investment and serious secondary pollution. The main components of chromium-containing leather waste are collagen, chromium oxide, fats and other inorganic substances and impurity metals (e.g. iron, magnesium, etc.), which account for 80 %, 4 %, 10.5 % and 5.5 % of the total weight, respectively[21]. Since the main component of chromium-containing leather waste is protein, it can provide an important carbon source for activated carbon production. In addition, some literatures[22,23] reported that the activated carbon with chromium-containing leather waste using as raw materials is rich in functional groups (carbonyl, carboxyl, hydroxyl, etc.), has a large specific surface area, and can offer excellent low-temperature catalytic oxidation activity after doping with active metals. Hence, the utilization of chromium-containing leather waste for the preparation of activated carbon carriers in the catalysis reaction may be a new method of resource utilization, which is significant for both the environment and biomass resources[10,24]. Currently, activated carbon as a carrier is widely employed in NH3-SCR reaction[25-27]. But it is rarely utilized in catalytic oxidation. Our team prepared a series of MnxCe1-xZr0.5/AC composite catalysts using leather waste as AC raw materials and found the catalyst Mn0.7Ce0.3Zr0.5/AC shows a good low-temperature NH3-SCR performances[28]. So, the feasibility of preparing activated carbon carriers from leather waste was demonstrated. Additionally, we also studied the CeCoOx catalyst for the VOCs oxidation, and found that the Ce/Co ratio and synthesis method is key for the catalytic activity, Co1Ce2Ox showed the optimal activity with T90 at 275 °C[29], but deeply investigation suggests that the CeCoOx particles is easy to aggregate in the simulated application condition, which consequently resulted in a decreased catalytic activity. In order to improve its stability and low-temperature catalytic oxidation activity, loading CeCoOx onto the activated carbon carriers from leather waste may be an effective strategy. In this study, Ce-Co binary oxide catalysts for toluene oxidation with different Ce/Co ratios were synthesized via a modified impregnation method using leather powder based activated carbon as the support material. A series of characterization techniques such as SEM, BET, XRD, H2-TPR, XPS and Raman were employed to further elaborate the structure-performance relationship of toluene removal by Ce-Co metal oxides. The reaction mechanism was investigated by in situ DRIFTS. The work may provide new ideas for the design of efficient de-VOCs catalysts. 2 Experiment 2.1 Catalyst synthesis Activated carbon supporting material (AC) is prepared by pretreatment, carbonization and activation steps using leather waste as raw material. The exact steps are shown in our previous study[29]. CeCoOx/AC was synthesized by a modified equal volume impregnation method. Firstly, the saturated water uptake of activated carbon (0.5 g) was measured by titration, and then the loading solution concentration was calculated with the required amount of metal ions of Ce(NO3)3·6H2O and Co(NO3)2·6H2O, after that the mixed solution was prepared and titrated. Upon completion of the titration, the samples were dried and then placed in a tube furnace for calcination in an N2 atmosphere to obtain the desired samples. The total loading of eight samples was set as 3.5 % Ce, 3.5 % Co, 3.5 % Ce 0.5 % Co, 0.5 % Ce 3.5 % Co, 1.5 % Ce 1.5 % Co, 2.5 % Ce 2.5 % Co, 3.5 % Ce 3.5 % Co, 4.5%Ce 4.5%Co and which is correspondingly named as AC-Ce3.5, AC-Co3.5, Ce3.5Co0.5AC, Ce0.5Co3.5AC, Ce1.5Co1.5AC, Ce2.5Co2.5AC, Ce3.5Co3.5AC, and Ce4.5Co4.5AC, respectively. 2.2 Catalyst characterization Specific details are shown in the support information. 2.3 Catalyst activity evaluation The catalysts were placed into quartz tubes with an inner diameter of 6 mm and tested for their catalytic activity towards toluene oxidation on a fixed bed reactor. About 0.1 g of catalyst sample was mixed with appropriate amount of quartz particles to prevent clogging, and quartz wool was placed at both ends of the sample to secure it in place. The length of the catalytic layer is about 30 mm and the test temperature ranges is 50 ℃ to 300 ℃. Toluene solution is brought into the reactor with N2, the toluene concentration is about 1000 ppm, the oxygen content is 20 Vol%, N2 is kept in equilibrium, and the corresponding gas air velocity is 110,000 ml·g−1·h−1. In order to preventing gas condensation on the tube wall, a heating tape was used and kept at 100 ℃ throughout the test. The concentration of toluene inlet and outlet of the reactor was monitored by the GC9790Ⅱ Foley Instruments gas chromatograph, and the change in toluene concentration was used to calculate the conversion of toluene as follows: (1) X Toluene ( % ) = Toluen e in − Toluen e out Toluen e in × 100 % The carbon dioxide yield is measured by GASBOARD GAS ANALYZER (3000 plus) and calculated by the follow formula: (2) Y Toall = [ C O 2 ] out CO 2 * × 100 % (3) Y Toluene = Y Toall − Y C Where [CO2]out is the carbon dioxide effluent concentration, CO 2 * is the carbon dioxide concentration when toluene is completely converted. Considering the specificity of carbon-based catalysts, the effect of carbon combustion needs to be excluded when calculating the CO2 selectivity of toluene. The reaction rate (r, μmol g−1s−1) was calculated by the follows: (4) r = 1000 × F · C · X 3600 × R Where F, C, and X denote the weighted hourly space velocity (mL· g−1·h−1), the initial toluene concentration, and the toluene conversion rate, respectively. R denotes the standard molar volume of gas (22.4 L·mol −1). The activation energy is obtained by the inverse of the Arrhenius equation. (5) lnr = lnA − E a RT Where A is pre-exponential factor, Ea is activation energy (kJ·mol −1), R is the molar gas constant (8.314 J·mol −1·K −1), T is reaction temperature (K). 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Textural characterization 3.1.1 XRD The activated carbon based catalysts loaded with Ce and Co were analyzed by XRD and shown in Fig. 1 . The peaks in the range of 43°−50° can be attributed to amorphous activated carbon. One can see that some characteristic diffraction peaks attributed to Co3O4 with a spinel structure (PDF No. 42-1467) and cubic CeO2 with a fluorite structure (PDF No. 44-1001) can be detected. Compared with AC-Ce3.5, the peak corresponded to CeO2 on the Ce0.5Co3.5AC catalyst is not obvious or even negligible, probably due to the formation of Ce-Co-O solid solution[30]. Compared with AC-Co3.5, the diffraction peaks intensity over Ce3.5Co0.5AC increases and the CeO2 peak gradually appears, indicative of the coexistence of Co3O4 and CeO2 mixed phases. In addition, the diffraction peaks of both Ce3.5Co0.5AC and Ce0.5Co3.5AC were slightly shifted to higher 2θ values compared to AC-Ce3.5 and AC-Co3.5, suggesting that there may be an interaction between cerium and cobalt resulted from the successful doping of Co species into the lattice of CeO2, leading to the distortion of lattice structure through the formation of Co-O-Ce mixed bonds in the CeCoOx/AC catalyst. The intensity of these diffraction peaks over Ce3.5Co3.5AC catalyst become weaker compare with others, indicating that CeO2 and Co3O4 are highly dispersed on the catalyst surface, and Ce3.5Co3.5AC catalysts have the inimitable degree of crystallinity and structural distortion. 3.1.2 Raman analysis Fig. 2 shows the Raman spectra, it can be observed in Fig. 2a that all samples have two stretching bands, D (1344.448 cm−1) and G (1594.185 cm−1), associated with the in-plane breathing vibration mode and the in-plane stretching vibration mode, respectively[31,32]. The D band depicts the defects and disorder in the graphite microcrystalline layer, while the G band is pertinent to the ordered graphite structure[33]. The strength ratios (ID/IG) of the D-band and G-band can be used to characterize the degree of order and graphite crystallinity of the carbon material[19,34]. In general, a higher ID/IG value means a higher irregularity degree and stronger adsorption capacity. The order of the ID/IG values of the serial catalysts is Ce3.5Co3.5AC (1.05) > Ce0.5Co3.5AC (1.03) > Ce3.5Co0.5AC (1.02). It can thus be observed that the ID/IG values and surface defects of the catalysts tend to increase with the growth of Ce and Co loadings, on the basis of which it can be inferred that modification of metal elements affects the oxygen-containing groups and surface defects of the catalysts[35]. Changes in oxygen-containing groups and surface defects caused by different metal doping ratios may produce different catalytic active sites, thus affecting the catalyst activity[36]. Based on the above analysis, it can be inferred that Ce3.5Co3.5AC may display the optimal catalytic performance among these samples. Alternatively, as demonstrated in Fig. 2b, the peak near 400 cm−1 can be attributed to the symmetric telescoping vibration of F2g in the cubic-phase CeO2-like fluorite structure[37]. The larger intensity of the half peak width of the CeO2 F2g mode in the Ce3.5Co3.5AC catalyst indicates the formation of many oxygen defects due to aliquot substitution of cobalt[38]. The band at 677 cm−1 corresponds to the A1g vibrational mode of octahedral Co3+-O in the Co3O4 spinel phase[39]. The peak at 597 cm−1 corresponds to a defect-induced mode, probably due to the presence of oxygen vacancies (Ov) in the CeO2 lattice due to the presence of Ce3+[30,40]. The order of oxygen vacancy concentrations for the Ov/F2g values obtained according to the calculation method of reference 41 is Ce3.5Co3.5AC (0.072) > Ce2.5Co2.5AC (0.048) > Ce1.5Co1.5AC (0.059)[41]. It is noteworthy that both CeO2 F2g and Co3O4 A1g peaks of Ce3.5Co3.5AC catalysts were slightly shifted to the lower frequency direction compared with Ce3.5Co0.5AC and Ce0.5Co3.5AC, which may be caused by Co-induced lattice distortion of CeO2 and formation of Ce-Co-O solid solution[42], in agreement with the XRD results. XRD and Raman results reveal that there may be a strong interaction between Co3O4 and CeO2, and such a strong interaction breaks the ordered structure of the catalyst, leading to more lattice defects and further promoting the formation of oxygen vacancies. To date, extensive studies have shown that oxygen vacancies in catalysts can foreshorten the metal-oxygen bond strength and promote the mobility of oxygen species, favoring the catalytic activity[11,43]. This resulted in the formation of oxygen vacancies and lattice defects in Ce3.5Co3.5AC catalyst, which may act as the main active sites for the oxidation of toluene. 3.1.3 SEM and N2 physisorption Figure S1 shows the SEM image of the raw activated carbon. It can be clearly observed that most of the activated carbon derived from leather powder was irregular block of stacked nanoparticles. And rich pore structures are distributed on the sample surface, which can provide attachment sites for active metals and beneficial to the adsorption. In addition, it can be inferred from Table 1 that the raw leather carbon has a large specific surface area and pore volume, which facilitates the acquisition of reaction centers[34]. As shown in Fig. 3 , Ce3.5Co3.5AC and leathery carbon have similar morphological structures, which suggests that the effect of metal element doping on the morphology of the catalysts is weak. Figure S2 in the supporting information shows the N2 adsorption-desorption isotherm and corresponding pore-size distributions of the serial CeCoOx/AC catalysts. It can be observed that catalysts show typical type I isotherms, the pore size distribution was relatively localized in the 0.4–0.7 nm range, indicative of the existence of numerous microporous structures, which suggests that loading the metal elements via the modified impregnation method almost altered pore structure of the activated carbon. The order of the specific surface area and pore volumes are shown in Table 1: AC > Ce3.5Co3.5AC > Ce2.5Co2.5AC > Ce0.5Co3.5AC > Ce3.5Co0.5AC. Although the loading of metal oxides would block some channels, subsequently decrease the specific surface area, plainly, the pore volumes of Ce3.5Co3.5AC and Ce2.5Co2.5AC are higher than those of Ce3.5Co0.5AC and Ce0.5Co3.5AC, suggesting that the pore volumes is enhanced accordingly with the increase of Ce and Co contents. It reveals that the introduction of Ce and Co is beneficial to the formation of mesoporous structures to a certain extent, a similar discovery was also reported by Hu et al.[44]. However, it can be clearly observed that Ce3.5Co3.5AC is minimally affected and thus has the largest specific surface area and pore volume among the series of catalysts. In general, the specific surface area is positively correlated with the number of active sites[16,45], thus it can be inferred that Ce3.5Co3.5AC facilitates the diffusion of toluene molecules and result in better activity. 3.2 Redox properties analysis 3.2.1 O2-TPD analyses In general, the active oxygen species play a key role on the catalytic oxidation of VOCs. In order to figure out the oxygen species type and mobility, O2-TPD test was conducted. As shown in Fig. 4 , all of the spectra over the serial catalysts have three desorption peaks, and the peaks below 300 ℃ are assigned to the weakly chemisorbed surface oxygen species Osur (O2−, O 2 2 − or O−), the peak located in the mid-temperature region is derived from the apparent lattice oxygen species Olat,α (O2−) and contributed by the lattice defects, the high temperature peak is associated with the lattice oxygen species Olat,β from the bulk metal oxides[36,46]. The O2-TPD results for AC, AC-Ce3.5 and AC-Co3.5 are shown in Figure S3 in the supporting information. Raw AC has only one desorption peak belonging to surface lattice oxygen. For AC-Ce3.5 and AC-Co3.5, desorption peaks are present for both adsorbed and lattice oxygen species[47]. The adsorbed oxygen peak over AC-Co3.5 is larger than the lattice oxygen, while the intensity of the lattice oxygen peak over AC-Ce3.5 is much stronger than the adsorbed oxygen, suggesting that AC-Co3.5 contains more surface adsorbed oxygen species, while AC-Ce3.5 is dominated by surface lattice oxygen species. It is clearly observed that the intensity of desorption peak assigned to the lattice oxygen in the medium to high temperature range increases significantly with the enhancement of Ce and Co doping amounts, confirming that the interaction between Ce and Co can boost the formation of surface and bulk lattice oxygen, which subsequently improve the reaction rate of catalytic oxidation[48]. Moreover, it is evident that the bimetallic doping of Ce and Co can benefit for the transformation of the surface-active oxygen species, thus affect the catalytic oxidation ability of the as-synthesized catalyst. In particular, the intensity of Olat,α contributed by lattice defects over Ce3.5Co3.5AC is significantly higher than that of Ce3.5Co0.5AC and Ce0.5Co3.5AC, evidence suggests that the lattice defects generated by the interaction between Ce and Co increase the lattice oxygen content, which favors an increase in the concentration of surface and subsurface oxygen vacancies in the catalysts, coinciding with Raman analyses. Thus, for the Ce3.5Co3.5AC sample, the desorption of lattice oxygen was shifted to a lower temperature compared to the other catalysts, followed by an increase in the intensity of desorption, and the easier desorption of the lattice oxygen indicated an increase in the mobility and activity of the lattice oxygen species in the samples[11]. As shown in Fig. 4b, the total O2 consumption shows a gradual upward trend with the grown of metal loadings, indicating that Ce and Co contents are intimately related to the oxidizing ability of the catalyst, the Ce3.5Co3.5AC catalyst has optimal lattice oxygen content and oxygen mobility, which contribute to the deep oxidation of toluene. 3.2.2 H2-TPR To illustrate the effect of the co-doping Ce and Co on the redox ability, H2-TPR characterization was performed, the results depicted in Fig. 5a and Fig. S4a in the supporting information. It can be clearly observed that all samples have four distinct reduction peaks, suggesting that there are three different oxygen species are reduced for CeCoOx/AC catalysts, surface adsorption oxygen species (100–400 ℃), surface lattice oxygen (400–600 ℃) and bulk lattice oxygen (600–800 ℃), respectively. The peaks located at 309–397 ℃ are assigned to the reduction of Co3O4 to CoO, and the peaks at 406–449 ℃ are assigned to the reduction of CoO to Co0[49]. The peak at 502–555 ℃ corresponds to the reduction of oxygen on the CeO2 surface, and peak at 617–701 ℃ is associated with the reduction of bulk Ce4+ to Ce3+[49]. It can be observed that the increase of Ce and Co doping amounts caused a significant shift of the Co3O4 reduction peak to a lower temperature, the order of Co3O4 reduction peak changes as follow: Ce3.5Co0.5AC (397 ℃) > Ce0.5Co3.5AC (381 ℃) > Ce1.5Co1.5AC (367 ℃) > Ce2.5Co2.5AC (330 ℃) > Ce3.5Co3.5AC (309 ℃), the appearance of the low-temperature reduction peaks may be due to the synergistic effect between Ce and Co, which tightly binds the Ce-O bond to the Co species, combined with the XRD results, the formation of Co-Ce-O solid solution is indicated. In addition, as can be observed in Figure S3(a), the reduction peaks of both AC-Ce3.5 and AC-Co3.5 are shifted toward lower temperature compared to pure activated carbon, indicating that the Ce and Co modification can significantly improve the low-temperature reduction ability of the catalysts. Apparently, an increase in the upload of Ce and Co would greatly change the reduction steps of CoO to Co0 and CeO2 surface oxygen, this change implies that there may be an interaction between Ce and Co which can activate the catalyst surface/subsurface lattice oxygen[50]. It's interesting, for the peaks assigned to the reduction Co2+ to Co0, the difference in the reduction peak temperature is not significant, indicating that the interaction mainly promotes the first reduction step of Co3O4 and increases the mobilities of lattice oxygen[51]. To achieve a better understanding of the reducing properties of CeCoOx/AC catalysts, the hydrogen consumption was calculated by the peak fitting in Fig. 5b. Clearly, Ce2.5Co2.5AC and Ce3.5Co3.5AC have larger hydrogen consumption compared with others, indicating that the two samples contain more active oxygen species and Ce-Co-O solid solution among them, the above analysis proves that the activation of lattice oxygen to form reactive oxygen species at low temperatures is related to the weakening of the metal-oxygen bond strength by oxygen vacancies, which is consistent with the XRD and O2-TPD results. For better comparison, the theoretical hydrogen consumption of each catalyst was also calculated based on the complete conversion of each step as shown in Table S1 and Figure S5 in the supporting information. By comparing the actual and theoretical hydrogen consumption for the reduction of Co3O4 to Co0 and bulk Ce4+ to Ce3+, their actual hydrogen consumption is much higher than the theoretical values. Collectively, the results analyzed above show that the surface lattice oxygen's favors CoO to Co0, which promotes the deep reduction of Co3O4, and thus the Co3O4 species on the Ce3.5Co3.5AC catalyst shows a better reducibility. Quaintly, the actual hydrogen consumption for the reduction of Ce4+ to Ce3+ is above the theoretical value, but the hydrogen consumption shows a declining trend with the increase of Ce and Co uploading (Ce1.5Co1.5AC(0.981 μ mol/g)>Ce2.5Co2.5AC(0.916 μ mol/g)>Ce3.5Co3.5AC(0.861 μ mol/g)), it is hypothesized that there may be electron transfer due to the interaction between Ce and Co, resulting in the formation of more Co3O4 and Ce3+, a finding consistent with the conclusions of Ismail et al.[52]. Therefore, the low-temperature reducibility and increased mobility of oxygen species in the Ce3.5Co3.5AC sample favor the cyclic regeneration of oxygen vacancies during the reaction. In summary, the large number of reactive oxygen species and oxygen vacancies gave Ce3.5Co3.5AC the state of the art redox capacity among the series of catalysts. 3.3 XPS analyze The chemical elemental composition and state of the serial catalysts were analyzed using XPS technique, and the obtained O 1s, Co 2p and Ce 3d C 1s spectra are displayed in Fig. 6 (C 1s spectra is displayed in Figure S6). The valence distribution of each element is summarized in Table S2. The O 1 s spectra (Fig. 6a) can be divided into three peaks with surface energies located in 528.5–528.93 eV, 529.0–529.46 eV, and 530.9–531.1 eV, respectively, which can be ascribed to metal cation bonded lattice oxygen (Olatt), surface chemisorbed oxygen (Osur), and other oxygen species (Oother)[39,53], respectively. The percentage of various oxygen species are listed in Table S2 in the supporting information, the increase in Ce and Co loadings will affect the lattice oxygen content, the lattice oxygen concentration of each catalyst is changed as follows: Ce3.5Co3.5AC (51.82 %) > Ce2.5Co2.5AC (51.58 %) > Ce1.5Co1.5AC (29.10 %), depletion of lattice oxygen may lead to the generation of more oxygen vacancies[39]. Combined with the O2-TPD analysis, it can be deduced that the metal atoms may play a key role in adsorption and activation of reactive molecules such as toluene, while the oxygen vacancies on the catalyst surface mainly convert the gaseous phase oxygen into the surface reactive oxygen species[54]. It is noteworthy that all oxygen peaks of the Ce3.5Co3.5AC catalyst shifted to higher binding energies compared to Ce3.5Co0.5AC and Ce0.5Co3.5AC, suggesting lower electron densities around the oxygen atoms[55]. In conjunction with the H2-TPR and activity results, it is hypothesized that in addition to surface oxygen vacancies, bulk vacancies can enhance the mobility and activity of lattice oxygen species through the transport effect of lattice oxygen species, thereby promoting the decomposition of the toluene aromatic ring and efficiently oxidizing toluene. Therefore, it is reasonable to believe that the synergistic interaction between Ce and Co can change the lattice oxygen concentration of the catalyst, thus generating more oxygen vacancies for superior lattice oxygen mobility and toluene conversion. The peaks at 794.5 eV and 779.8 eV-780.2 eV in Fig. 6b are attributed to Co2+ and Co3+, respectively, and the peaks at other positions are satellite peaks of Co elements[56,57]. In general, Co3+ is the main active substance in catalytic oxidation reactions and plays a key role in the low-temperature catalytic activity[58,59]. Therefore, the Co3+ concentration is an important indicator of the catalytic oxidation properties in the CeCoOx/AC catalyst system[57]. It can be observed from Table 2 that the Ce3.5Co3.5AC catalyst has the highest Co3+/Co2+ ratio, corroborating the above H2-TPR inference, which implies that it may have superior low temperature catalytic performance compared with others. The Ce 3d XPS of Ce3.5Co0.5AC, Ce0.5Co3.5AC, Ce1.5Co1.5AC, Ce2.5Co2.5AC and Ce3.5Co3.5AC catalysts are displayed in Fig. 6c. The peaks at 916.0 eV, 906.9 eV, 900.0–900.45 eV, 888.0–888.4 eV and 916.0 eV are related to Ce4+, the peaks at 897.6–897.9 eV and 882.0–882.1 eV are attributed to Ce3+[11,59], respectively. According to the spectral changes, it can be found that the chemical valence state of Ce over the serial catalysts is mainly dominated by Ce4+, and Ce3+ accounts for a relatively small amount. With the increase of metal loadings, the Ce3+ contents showed a gradual increase as Ce4+ was reduced. Among them, Ce3.5Co3.5AC catalyst has the largest content of Ce3+. It is always believed that Ce3+ can form chemical bonds with unbalanced charge and unsaturated vacancies on the catalyst surface, subsequently facilitates the formation of weakly bonded oxygen species[60], this is consistent with the previous XRD and Raman results. Integrating the H2-TPR and O2-TPD results, it is demonstrated that there is a strong interaction between Ce and Co, which generates more Ce3+ and Co3+ on the Ce3.5Co3.5AC surface, facilitating the electron transfer and the cycling of the oxygen vacancies, and thus there is an increase in the mobility of the lattice oxygen[44,61]. Consequently, this analysis indicates that Ce3.5Co3.5AC catalyst may display the optimal catalytic oxidation activity among the serial catalysts. Combining the Fig. 4 and Fig. 5, it can be hypothesized as following reaction gas firstly adsorb on the catalyst surface, subsequently react with neighboring lattice oxygen species, with the lattice oxygen being consumed, oxygen vacancies are generated, and the gas-phase oxygen molecules subsequently fill these oxygen vacancies, forming a cycle which enhances lattice oxygen mobility. The strong interaction between Ce and Co in Ce3.5Co3.5AC catalyst is conductive to produce lattice oxygen and promote the mobility, which are considered to be the key factors in promoting catalytic oxidation of toluene in the Ce-Co/AC catalyst system. 3.4 Catalytic performance 3.4.1 Catalyst activity Fig. 7 demonstrates the performance of the as-prepared CeCoOx/AC samples for the low-temperature catalytic oxidation of toluene at varying temperatures, in which the reaction temperature of toluene conversion of 90 % (T90) was used to evaluate the activity of the catalysts. As shown in Fig. 7a, the single AC supporting material has the worst toluene removal efficiency, and its catalytic activity is slightly improved by loading monometallic of Ce or Co, but the improvement effect is unsatisfactory. As expected, the catalytic oxidation ability of catalysts is remarkably enhanced via the co-doping Ce and Co compare with that of the single metal catalyst, implying that there is interaction between Ce and Co. As shown in Fig. 7b, both Ce3.5Co0.5AC and Ce0.5Co3.5AC catalysts shows lower toluene removal efficiencies than Ce1.5Co1.5AC, Ce2.5Co2.5AC, Ce3.5Co3.5AC and Ce4.5Co4.5AC, in which Ce3.5Co3.5AC catalyst display the optimal catalytic oxidation performance (T90 = 246 ℃), Ce2.5Co2.5AC, Ce1.5Co1.5AC and Ce4.5Co4.5AC follows closely. The above results suggest that the loading level and Ce/Co ratio have a great influence on the activity, and the catalysts have the optimal activity when the loading level is 3.5 wt% for both Ce and Co. The toluene conversion over Ce4.5Co4.5AC was lower than that of Ce3.5Co3.5AC, which should be due to the excessive metal uploading clogged the active sites of the catalyst. Furthermore, a comparison with Fig. 7a reveals that both Ce3.5Co0.5AC and Ce0.5Co3.5AC catalysts have better activity than the monometallic loaded AC-Ce3.5 and AC-Co3.5, confirming that there is a synergistic effect between Ce and Co. The CO2 selectivity of the prepared catalysts showed the same upward trend during the reaction (Fig. 7c and d). To illustrate the inherent catalytic differences in the catalysts, Fig. 7e and f shows an Arrhenius scatter plot for the catalytic oxidation of toluene, from which the apparent activation energy (Ea) of the individual catalysts can be calculated. The Ea values of Ce3.5Co3.5AC, Ce2.5Co2.5AC and Ce1.5Co1.5AC, were 11.66, 15.39, and 17.60 kJ·mol−1, respectively, the values are substantially lower than those of the other catalysts in the serial samples, suggesting the activation energy of toluene oxidation over CeCoOx/AC samples is greatly reduced due to the interaction between Ce and Co. From Table 2 and Fig. 6, the T90 for toluene oxidation of the catalyst is indeed shows positive correlation with the Olatt concentration calculated by XPS results. Besides, Raman, O2-TPD, H2-TPR, XPS and reaction activation results were analyzed for various catalysts. It is hypothesized that the interaction between Ce and Co facilitated the generation of lattice defects, oxygen vacancies and lattice oxygen content, consequently improved the mobility of lattice oxygen, which is also evidenced by the enhanced reducibility of CeCoOx/AC. The oxygen vacancies and lattice oxygen mobility in CeCoOx/AC could be the initial reason for the excellent low-temperature catalytic activity of the CeCoOx/AC catalysts for the toluene oxidation. Moreover, compared with the reported literature (Table 3 ), the Ce3.5Co3.5AC catalyst exhibited the expected catalytic activity for toluene oxidation, which may be due to the rich pore structure and large specific surface area of the activated carbon carrier, that can provide more active sites. What's more, the stronger adsorption capacity could also accelerate the conversion of toluene to some extent. The catalytic ability of the catalyst was significantly improved after loading metal elements, probably due to the interaction between Ce and Co, this leads to lattice defects, increased lattice oxygen, surface Ce3+ and Co3+ content, cycling of oxygen vacancies and excellent lattice oxygen mobility, which are multifactorial factors that synergistically contribute to the catalytic oxidation of toluene. 3.4.2 Water resistance and stability The stability of high humidity is an important factor in the practical application of toluene degradation. The water-tolerance on Ce3.5Co3.5AC catalyst in Fig. 8a exhibited that when the water vapor was introduced, the toluene conversion presented a downward trend. The toluene conversion efficiency decreased rapidly from 98 % to 40 % at 250 °C with the introduction of 10 vol% water vapor, which is mainly due to the compete adsorption of water molecules and toluene[53,66]. Interestingly, the toluene conversion efficiency gradually increased with reaction time and finally reached a plateau with remaining at about 64 %. It may be due to the reason that there are a large number of hydroxyl groups on the catalyst surface, which can be activated by water vapor, consequently increase the catalytic reaction rate by activating the OO bond to enhance the replenishment of active O2[10]. When the passage of water vapor was stopped, the conversion of toluene gradually returned to the preliminary level, also still remained stable after 2 h, proving that the Ce3.5Co3.5AC catalyst had good water resistance ability. Furthermore, the stability at 250 ℃ for 50 h was investigated on a Ce3.5Co3.5AC catalyst. As shown in Fig. 8b, the toluene conversion rate was above 90 % for the first ten hours, then dropped to about 80 % after twenty hours, while the toluene conversion rate was basically maintained at 70 % after 35 h. It can be attributed to the reason that the activated carbon will be consumed during the catalytic oxidation process and thus reducing the activity. The H2-TPR results in Figure S7 demonstrated that its low-temperature reduction peaks of the catalyst after the stability test shifted to high temperatures and the overall peak area decreased, indicative of a weakening of the catalyst's reduction capacity, which is consistent with the activity results. Considering that activated carbon is oxidized at high temperatures, we performed activity and stability tests on the prepared Ce3.5Co3.5AC catalyst under simulated practical industrial conditions, and the results are shown in Figure S11. In summary, the Ce3.5Co3.5AC has good water resistance and stability. 3.4.3 Toluene concentration and WHSV effects over Ce3.5Co3.5AC catalyst In practical industrial applications condition, the instability of toluene concentration and air speed also affects the performance of catalysts, so it is essential to investigate the effects of toluene concentration and air speed on the de-VOCs ability. As shown in Fig. 9a , the toluene concentration from 500 to 2000 ppm influenced the catalytic-activity for 110,000 ml·g−1·h−1 WHSV over the Ce3.5Co3.5AC catalyst. It is clearly observed that toluene concentration has a slight effect on catalytic activity, but the magnitude of the effect varies across the concentration range. In brief, the conversion did not decrease significantly with the increase of toluene concentration, and T90 = 268 ℃ at 2000 ppm toluene concentration indicated that Ce3.5Co3.5AC had better catalytic activity for high toluene concentration. Shown in Table 3, the GHSV of most Ce-Co metal oxide catalysts for toluene catalytic oxidation applications ranges from about 10,000 - 30,000 h−1, so WHSV =74,000, 110,000 and 220,000 ml·g−1·h−1 were selected in this study to explore the application potential of the Ce3.5Co3.5AC catalyst for simulated real-world working conditions. The effect of WHSV on toluene oxidation ability over Ce3.5Co3.5AC catalyst at 1000 ppm toluene was investigated as shown in Fig. 9b. When the WHSV drops to 74,000 ml·g−1·h−1, its T90 drops to 242 ℃. On the contrary, when WHSV increases to 220,000 ml·g−1·h−1, T90 rises to 287 ℃, which is 45 ℃ higher than those under 74,000 ml·g−1·h−1. The results exhibit that Ce3.5Co3.5AC performs better catalytic toluene oxidation ability at lower WHSV. In summary, the Ce3.5Co3.5AC catalyst have good resistance to toluene concentration and airspeed, and have the potential to be used in practical applications. 3.5 In situ DRIFTS In this study, toluene oxidation was chosen as a model reaction to investigate the character and intermediates of oxygen species on Ce3.5Co3.5AC and AC by in situ DRIFTS. Ce3.5Co3.5AC and AC were pretreated in pure N2 at 300 ℃ for 60 min to remove surface adsorbed oxygen species, and then1000ppm toluene was introduced into the reactor to record DRIFTS at different temperatures. As is shown in Fig. 10a , the distinctive characteristic peaks at 3210 cm−1 and 1190 cm−1 are attributed to the stretching vibration of the aromatic ring and the CO stretching of the benzyl alcohol salt species, respectively[10,11,62]. The peaks of 1405 cm−1 and 1535 cm−1 are attributed to carboxylate groups and represent the CO stretching vibration and antisymmetric CO stretching vibration of benzoate species, respectively[11,54]. The observed bands at 1677 cm−1 belong to the benzaldehyde species[10]. The characteristic peaks of various species on the Ce3.5Co3.5AC catalyst were evident at low temperatures (50 ℃), indicative of strong adsorption and oxidation of toluene on the catalyst surface. It is clearly observed that the intensity of the benzyl alcohol peak decreases with increasing reaction temperature, while on the contrary, the intensity of the benzoate peak increases, indicating that the oxidation rate of toluene is accelerated at high temperatures, which may be due to the depletion of the lattice oxygen species, leading to a decrease in the rate of deeper oxidation of the benzoate species, which is partially accumulated on the catalyst surface. Both benzyl alcohol and benzoate are the major intermediates. It is widely accepted that the oxidation of benzoate esters is a key step in the oxidation of toluene[11]. In addition, the characteristic peaks of intermediates assigned to toluene oxidation aromatic rings (3150 and 3030 cm−1)[46,54], benzaldehyde (1677 cm−1)[67], and benzoate (1397 and 1528 cm−1)[36] can be found in Fig. 10c, however, it is apparent that the peak intensity of the AC catalyst intermediate species is less than that of Ce3.5Co3.5AC, illustrating that the lattice oxygen activity of Ce3.5Co3.5AC is superior to that of AC and is favorable for toluene oxidation. Accordingly, the interaction of Ce and Co on Ce3.5Co3.5AC can enhance the activity of its lattice oxygen species. Ce3.5Co3.5AC and AC were pretreated at 300 ℃ with pure N2 for 60 min (Fig. 10b and d) to remove adsorbed oxygen species, and then a gas mixture (20 % O2 and toluene) was introduced in an IR reactor to record the spectra at 200 °C. One can clearly see that the intensity of the characteristic peaks is different on Ce3.5Co3.5AC in the presence of gaseous oxygen species compared to Fig. 10a. As shown in Fig. 10b, the peaks assigned to the benzoate esters gradually decreased with reaction time and their intermediate product peak intensities remained uniform compared to Fig. 10a, indicating that deep oxidation of toluene was exhibited in the presence of gaseous oxygen supplementation. Compared with Fig. 10c, there was no significant change in the intensity of the Fig. 10d intermediate peak, indicating that the oxidizing ability and mobility of the oxygen species on the AC were inferior. From all the above results, it can be concluded that Ce3.5Co3.5AC has excellent oxygen species mobility, which is consistent with the rapid oxygen cycling results demonstrated by O2-TPD results. Comparing Fig. 10d with Fig. 10b, it can be noticed that more intermediate species are generated on the surface of Ce3.5Co3.5AC catalyst with obvious changes in the pattern, and the characteristic IR peaks of the intermediates (1025 cm−1, 1175 cm−1, 1224 cm−1, alcohol salts; 1400 cm−1, 1525 cm−1 benzoates.) are calculated from the integrated area (Fig. 10e). The amount of alcohol salt on the surface can be found to decrease with reaction time, while the amount of benzoate increases over time, proving once again that alcohol salt and benzoate are the main intermediates[38]. It is well known that the catalytic oxidation of VOCs by transition metal oxide catalysts mostly follows the MVK mechanism[68]. Combining the MVK mechanism and our results, the oxidation of toluene proceeds as follows: toluene - benzyl alcohol - benzaldehyde - benzoate -...... - CO2 and H2O, agree well with described in the literature[11,46]. According to the MVK mechanism, surface lattice oxygen firstly oxidizes VOC molecules adsorbed on the catalyst surface, and then the bulk or gaseous oxygen is activated to replenish the surface lattice oxygen depleted during the VOC oxidation process[62,69]. Thus, the content of surface lattice oxygen and the mobility of the oxygen species are key factors in determining the catalyst activity[54]. Based on the above characterization results and analysis, it can be made the following speculation: surface lattice oxygen species act as reactive oxygen species to rapidly oxidize VOC molecules, oxygen vacancies are created when lattice oxygen is consumed, and then gaseous or bulk oxygen species is replenished to the adjacent oxygen vacancies to form new lattice oxygen, and this cycle continues, leading to superior reaction rates[7,44]. What is more, the poor oxygen species mobility of the AC catalyst slows down the replenishment of surface lattice oxygen species, resulting in a causal catalytic performance far weaker than that of Ce3.5Co3.5AC due to the lack of surface lattice oxygen species. In the contrary, Ce3.5Co3.5AC with excellent catalytic performance are mainly attributed to its more active lattice oxygen species and considerably greater oxygen species mobility. The above analysis again demonstrates that the interaction between Ce and Co favors the lattice oxygen activity and oxygen mobility of the catalyst, thus favoring the superior catalytic oxidation ability. 3.6 Synergies between Ce and Co species It is well known that for transition metal oxides, the redox capacity (oxygen mobility) and oxygen vacancies (oxygen adsorption and activation capacity, oxygen species) are the key factors determining the catalytic oxidation capacity[9,30]. Therefore, the amount of ligand-unsaturated Co3+ and Ce3+ in CeCoOx/AC catalysts has a striking effect on the redox properties, since the reducing properties of the catalysts are closely related to the redox cycling between Co3+ and Ce3+ ions, which are considered to be the driving force in the oxidation of VOCs[46,62]. The molar ratios of Co3+/Co2+ and Ce3+/Ce4+ are higher, the redox capacity and oxygen mobility are enhanced. In the present study, according to the MVK mechanism, activated toluene molecules were first oxidized by reactive lattice oxygen species, accompanied by the formation of oxygen vacancies[39]. At the same time, gaseous O2 molecules were adsorbed onto the oxygen vacancies to replenish the depleted lattice oxygen species. So it can be concluded that oxygen vacancies and lattice oxygen content play a decisive role in the catalytic oxidation of toluene. As shown in Fig. 11 , the reaction rate of the catalyst is plotted on a scale with the conformational relationship between the Olatt/Oads ratio, oxygen vacancy (Ov) concentration, surface Co3+/Co2+, and Ce3+/Ce4+ molar ratios. First, the Co is successful doping of into the CeO2 lattice, forming a Ce-Co-O solid solution, which slashes the strength of metal-oxygen bonding and thereby enhances the redox capacity, also, it facilitates the interaction between Ce and Co. In addition, the interaction between Ce and Co produces more oxygen vacancies and lattice oxygen species, which promotes oxygen adsorption, activation and improves oxygen mobility. Furthermore, the interaction favors the production of more Co3+ and Ce3+species, implying the reduction of lattice oxygen and better low-temperature reducibility. Among a series of prepared catalysts, the Ce3.5Co3.5AC catalyst has greater toluene adsorption and activation capacity, stronger reducibility and oxygen mobility, more oxygen vacancies and lattice oxygen species, which resulted in a synergistic effect between these multiple factors and responsible for its optimal catalytic oxidation activity. 4 Conclusion In this paper, composite metal oxides with different Ce and Co contents were synthesized by using activated carbon fired from leather powder as a carrier and applied to the catalytic oxidation of toluene. The results evidence that the Ce3.5Co3.5AC catalyst has the optimal oxidation performance for toluene with T90 = 246 ℃. In addition, the Ce3.5Co3.5AC catalyst has a good durability. Various characterization results indicate that the creation of lattice defects induces the interaction between Ce and Co, which facilitates the production of more Ce3+ and Co3+ species, promotes the formation of oxygen vacancies and lattice oxygen, and enhances the mobility of lattice oxygen species. The synergistic effect accounts for its significantly increased catalytic activity over the Ce3.5Co3.5AC catalyst. As well, in situ DRIFTS studies have shown that the catalytic toluene oxidation process obeys the MVK mechanisms. coredata.dc:description: A series of CeCoOx/AC catalysts using leather waste based activated carbon as the carrier were prepared by a modified impregnation method, and the catalytic performance of toluene oxidation was investigated. Among them, Ce3.5Co3.5AC catalyst with Ce and Co loading being both 3.5 wt% exhibited the optimal catalytic activity (T90 = 246 ℃). SEM (Scanning Electron Microscope), Raman, XRD (X-ray Diffraction), H2-TPR (Hydrogen Temperature Programmed Reduction), O2-TPD (Oxygen Temperature Programmed Desorption) and XPS (X-ray Photoelectron Spectroscopy) characterization results revealed that there is interaction between Ce and Co, leading to improved redox ability and oxygen mobility, more oxygen vacancies and lattice oxygen, higher Ce3+/Ce4+ and Co3+/Co2+ ratio, multi-factorial synergies which are positively responsible for its superior catalytic activity. Additionally, the in situ DRIFTS results on Ce3.5Co3.5AC catalyst verified that benzyl alcohol, benzoate are the main intermediates. Meanwhile, Ce3.5Co3.5AC catalyst has good resistance ability to water (10 Vol%) and catalytic stability, which has the potential to be applied in practice.

coredata.dc:title: CeCoOx/AC catalysts with synergistic effect for toluene catalytic oxidation: Insights into the contribution of lattice oxygen content and superior oxygen mobility
